At that time, Vajra Treasury Bodhisattva addressed the assembly of bodhisattvas, saying:
Only, all Buddha's disciples!

If a bodhisattva in the seventh stage has well cultivated discernment, with wisdom and skillful means well purifying the paths, well gathering provisions, well making great vows, well receiving the empowerment of the TathÄgata's abiding, attaining the power of his own wholesome roots, and the nature of being upheld, following the TathÄgata's powers, fearlessnesses, and unique qualities while practicing;

the beginning, middle, and end are all completely equal, because in suchness there is no discrimination, entering omniscience.

This bodhisattva, far removed from all the discriminations and false imaginations of mind, thought, and consciousness, without attachment, manifesting in equality with space, is said to have attained the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas.

The bodhisattva, having accomplished such forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas, as soon as he realizes the bodhisattva's immovable ground, attains a profound abiding that is difficult to understand, the same without distinctions, free from all characteristics, ceasing all attachments to thoughts, immeasurable and boundless, with all Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas unable to overpower it, with quiescence manifest.

In the same way, as soon as the bodhisattva attains the stage of Immovability, he also becomes free from all effort and spontaneously attains effortless nature, far removed from all bodily, verbal, and mental activities, abiding in the karmic retribution.
Buddha's disciple!

It is like a person who dreams that his body falls into a great river. In order to cross it, he gives rise to great courage and vigor. Because of giving rise to great courage and vigor, he immediately awakens from the dream.
After awakening from the dream, all the vigorous and urgent activities he did are completely at rest.
Buddha's disciple!

The bodhisattva is also like this. Seeing the mass of sentient beings falling into the four great torrents of afflictions, in order to save and liberate them, he gives rise to great courage and vigor. Because of giving rise to great diligence, as soon as he reaches the bodhisattva's stage of Immovability, all efforts are completely at rest;
All the two graspings and appearances of the bodhisattva no longer appear.
Buddha's disciple!
It is like a celestial immortal born in the Brahma world, whose afflictions of the desire realm never manifest.
Buddha's disciple!
When a bodhisattva abides in this Immovable Ground, the activities of all mind, thought, and consciousness no longer manifest.

Moreover, even the activities of the buddhas, the activities of enlightenment, the activities of bodhisattvas, and the activities of nirvana do not manifest, let alone the arising of worldly activities.

When a bodhisattva thus practices this eighth Immovable Ground, abiding in the power of upholding the original vow, he then, in this Dharma gate's swift current, is awakened and encouraged by the tathÄgatas;

'Excellent, excellent!
